awd_titl_txt: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Cost-Effective Energy Efficiency Management of Sustainable Manufacturing Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this award is to establish a systems view of energy efficiency in manufacturing systems, and to design a real-time control for a cost-effective and energy-efficient sustainable manufacturing system. Conventionally, improving productivity has been the primary research focus in the literature on manufacturing systems, and little attention has been paid to the systematic study of the complex issue of simultaneously reducing energy consumption and minimizing production cost. This research utilizes the opportunity offered by modern smart production equipment with multiple-energy consumption states/modes (instead of just on and off) to reduce energy consumption. The objective is to dynamically control each machine to achieve system optimality and maintain production goal. A semi-Markov decision process framework for the modeling and optimization of production processes is proposed that minimizes the energy consumption and overall system cost. Approximation methods will be developed to find near-optimal operational solutions. 

This project includes the formulation and systematic study of an extremely important problem that is faced by the U.S. industry today, and the development of a framework for dynamically determining the production policy that minimizes energy consumption and overall system cost. If successful, this research will result in a deeper understanding of the optimal operational structure of manufacturing system in the green world today, and eventually will lead to economical and environmental impact. This project will closely integrate with the training of graduate as well as undergraduate students, especially female and underrepresented minority students. The ideas and results will be broadly disseminated through classroom teachings, conference presentations, and journal publications. The transformative impact shall come from our close collaboration with industrial partners, student summer interns, and the implementation of the research findings.

por.por_cntn:
The research objectives of this NSF funded project are to establish a systems view of energy efficiency in manufacturing systems, and to design a real-time control for a cost-effective and energy-efficient sustainable manufacturing system, considering the fact that previous research mainly focuses on single machine or single process while largely neglecting energy consumption efficiency in typical multi-machine systems.

For intellectual merit, this research has established a systems view of energy efficiency in manufacturing environment and developed an integrated energy consumption and production management system using smart manufacturing devices. A semi-Markov decision process framework for the modeling and optimization of production process has been established to minimize the energy consumption and overall production cost.

For broader impacts, this research resulted in a deeper understanding of the optimal operational structure of manufacturing system in the green world, and eventually will lead to economical and environmental impact. The ideas and results of this project have been broadly disseminated through classroom teachings, conference presentations, journal publications, and industrial collaboration.

Thirteen journal papers and ten conference papers have been published based on the research outcomes of this NSF funded project. Two Ph.D students supported by this project have graduated and become the tenure-track assistant professors in the area of advanced manufacturing at the State University of New York at Binghamton and the Missouri University of Science and Technology. Three REU supplements have been obtained and supported eight undergraduate students to work on this project, including seven female undergraduate students and one African American undergraduate student. One of these undergraduate students has continued her research as Ph.D student in the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago. Both software and hardware test beds have been established in the Sustainable Manufacturing Systems Research Laboratory at the University of Illinos at Chicago. These facilities will be further expanded for continued research and education activities and for demonstration and test bed for K-12 students and teachers.
